slides.notes: After this topic, you will be able to: Understand the role of protocols in networking; Explain the reason for a layered architecture; Describe the OSI model in relation to layers, functions, protocols, and devices; Identify the five layers of the TCP/IP model.
Protocols define rules for communication. They dictate how data can be exchanged between devices and are maintained by organizations like IEEE and ANSI.

topics.title: Role of Protocols
keyPoints: Protocols establish rules for data communication.
Protocols are logical and ensure smooth data exchange between devices.

topics.title: OSI and TCP/IP Models
keyPoints: The OSI model provides a structured approach for designing network protocols.
TCP/IP has five layers, focusing on interoperability across various devices.

slides.notes: By the end of this lesson you should be able to describe the IEEE standard project 802 and various LAN technologies.
Standards describe Layer 1 and 2 implementations, with subdivisions like LLC and MAC in the data link layer.

topics.title: IEEE Standards
keyPoints: IEEE 802 standards define LAN implementations at OSI Layer 1 and 2.
IEEE subdivides data link layer into LLC and MAC sublayers.

topics.title: LAN Technologies
keyPoints: Ethernet, Token ring, FDDI, and ATM are primary LAN technologies.
Each technology has unique specifications and use cases.

slides.notes: You should be able to describe LAN infrastructure, network design, methodology, and understand layer 1, 2, and 3 design.
Network infrastructure includes physical and logical components for connectivity, security, and management.

topics.title: Physical Infrastructure
keyPoints: Physical infrastructure involves cabling, routers, switches, hubs, and NICs.
It is fundamental to supporting connectivity and communication.

topics.title: Logical Infrastructure
keyPoints: Logical infrastructure includes protocols, addressing, and server roles.
Essential for enabling network software components to interact.

slides.notes: Identify general characteristics of physical media, primary cable types, and structured cabling components.
Important characteristics include bandwidth, length limits, and interference susceptibility.

topics.title: Cable Types
keyPoints: Common types are coaxial, twisted-pair, and fiber-optic cables.
Each type has different interference and bandwidth capabilities.

topics.title: Structured Cabling
keyPoints: Structured cabling is based on hierarchical designs and follows standards like TIA/EIA.
It supports efficient data transmission across network components.

slides.notes: Describe switching techniques: circuit, message, and packet switching.
Switching involves data transfer between nodes in large networks with multiple devices.

topics.title: Switching Techniques
keyPoints: Circuit switching provides a dedicated path but is inefficient.
Message and packet switching allow data transfer without dedicated paths.

topics.title: Packet Switching
keyPoints: Data is divided into packets, which are routed independently.
Efficient for data that can tolerate small delays, like web browsing.

slides.notes: Describe WAN characteristics, standards, and technologies.
WAN standards operate at OSI layers 1 and 2, defining protocols for physical and data link layers.

topics.title: WAN Technologies
keyPoints: WANs operate over large geographical areas using technologies like ISDN, Frame Relay, and ATM.
They connect multiple LANs through carrier networks.

topics.title: Types of WANs
keyPoints: Switched WANs and point-to-point WANs are primary types.
Switched WANs provide connections between networks through intermediate nodes.
